attachment.data:
Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Age: 43

Sex: Male

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient reported a 1-month history of spontaneous clear left side nipple discharge with a recent appearance of a homolateral painless breast swelling.

History and Physical Examination:
The patient had a past medical history pertinent for obesity class I and bilateral hypoacusia for otosclerosis. On physical examination, he was an overweight Caucasian male with symmetrical breasts. On palpation, there was a bilateral pseudogynaecomastia with a smooth, ill-defined left breast thickening, especially at the union of the outer quadrants. With applied pressure, a minimal clear stream of discharge fluid was elicited from the left nipple and was felt to be localized to a single duct.

Medical Condition:
Patient was diagnosed with an intraductal papilloma (IP) with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and a single focus of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) solid-cribriform type, which was surgically removed by a left subcutaneous nipple-sparing mastectomy without sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Treatment:
The patient did not undergo axillary dissection and was administered tamoxifen as approved adjuvant hormone treatment for men with ER-positive early stage breast cancer.

Follow-up:
The patient was noted to be doing well 6 months post-operatively and is still on follow-up at the time of writing.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Intraductal papilloma (IP) with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and a single focus of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) solid-cribriform type.

Recommendations:
Follow-up with the multidisciplinary team for further management.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Medication:
N/A.

Discharge Instructions:
N/A.

Signed,
[Doctor's Name], MD.
